history.content:
Haven’t you already made the same post earlier?

I’m not sure anyone else is doing the same schedule. But for those that are planning to take two technicals over the summer, reconsider if you haven’t taken any similar difficultly technicals at Berkeley or don’t have competitive math and programming experience.

Congrats on getting accepted to Berkeley as an EECS transfer. I hope for your success at Cal. Just keep in mind that your first class here might be more than you expect, so it’s recommended that you only take one technical over summer and/or two technicals during fall. Even as a transfer, you still have time to ramp up the number of classes you are taking starting your first spring semester. You are coming to Cal, so you have the potential; remember to keep working hard cause that’s what got you here.

children.subject:
It’s definitely doable, but for his first experience into Cal to be two technicals during the accelerated 8 week session might a bit too much. You don’t know what you don’t know.

I applaud you doing exceptionally well in those two classes over the normal semester, and in hindsight you gauged that it’s doable for you over summer with your impressive background. I’m not exactly trying to dissuade OP from taking his first class over summer, but I just want him to take a good look at his skills before jumping into anything too rashly. I think we agree on that regard.

I also would not recommend taking 61A and 70 together. Both are very high workload just on their own, especially since courses need to condense all their material within that 2 month timeframe. I TAd for summer 61A in the past and in general, students who took another CS class (Data 8, CS 70, even CS 61B) along with 61A were stressed and really had a lot of their plate.
It seems like OP is deadset on taking both together. He probably has never dropped a class before and doesn’t see that as an option right now.

Yes, I agree that taking these two courses, especially over the summer as an incoming transfer, shouldn't be taken lightly. Even with extensive math/CS background (10 on AIME/USACO Platinum), CS 61A was not an easy class because of how tricky the tests were. I did manage to get an A/A+ respectively in those classes, but it was A LOT harder and more stressful than I imagined. Since the summer is even more intensive, I would advise that you don't bite off more than you can chew. That being said, if you still want to take these courses, then go ahead. I'm sure if you work hard enough, they will be doable.

history.content:
